subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... I m far from a Smalltalk expert, so if somebody is please correct me. However, that s not my understanding. What I think is the case is that in Smalltalk
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> I think Smalltalk does this. If you want to mark methods private, you
> put them in a protocol that suggests they shouldn't be used directly.

I'm far from a Smalltalk expert, so if somebody is please correct me.
However, that's not my understanding. What I think is the case is that
in Smalltalk access protection is object-scoped rather than
class-scoped. In Smalltalk, any object can see all of its members,
including members declared private in a superclass, but not the private
members of its sibling objects and unrelated objects. Thus Smalltalk
private is a little more like Java protected, though still not quite the
same thing. However, privacy is still stronger than just a suggestion.

--
